title: Ecosystems and Food Chains

vocab.definition: All the living and non-living things in an environment that interact with each other
The path that energy and nutrients follow as organisms eat other organisms
An organism that makes its own food, usually plants
An organism that gets energy by eating other organisms
An organism that breaks down dead plants and animals
A network of many connected food chains in an ecosystem
A consumer that eats only plants
A consumer that eats other animals
A consumer that eats both plants and animals
An animal that is hunted and eaten by a predator
An animal that hunts and eats other animals
How energy moves from the sun to producers and then to consumers
The process plants use to make food using sunlight, water, and carbon dioxide
An organism that makes its own food (producer)
An organism that must eat other organisms for energy (consumer)
A level in a food chain or web (producer, consumer types)
Consumer levels based on how far they are from producers
An animal that eats dead animals it did not kill
Anything that has mass and takes up space; material in organisms and the environment
Who eats whom in an ecosystem
A route or sequence, like a step in a food chain
A set of many connections, like a food web
To keep safe from harm or damage
The variety of living things in an ecosystem

teachingNotes: Use diagrams and real examples to show food chains. Discuss the flow of energy from sun to producers to consumers. Explore local ecosystems and identify the roles of different organisms.
